FOOD WASTE 
Food loss and waste is a major issue in 
America, where the U.S. Department of 
Agriculture (USDA) has estimated that 30-
40 percent of food is wasted . Meanwhile, 
food insecurity is an enormous problem in 
nearly every community. Food loss and waste 
also negatively impacts our environment by 
wasting precious resources and emitting 
methane. Food loss and waste anywhere is 
unacceptable, and we are dedicated to making 
sizeable improvements in our own operations 
so that less food is wasted.
2020 PROGRESS
55% OF FOOD WASTE DIVERTED 
FROM LANDFILL
In 2020, we launched a cross-functional 
internal effort to reduce our food waste and 
divert unsaleable food to beneficial recovery, 
whenever possible. This effort follows the EPA 
Food Recovery Hierarchy and aligns with the 
EPA and USDA joint goal to halve food waste 
by 2030. Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, we 
were unable to complete waste audits at our 
distribution centers as we had in 2019. As 
a result, we carried forward the same food 
waste percentage estimates used in our 2019 
calculations. We plan to complete additional 
waste audits as soon as travel restrictions 
allow, and we can do so safely.Despite being unable to repeat our food waste 
audits at distribution centers, we’re confident 
that there is more excess and unsellable food 
that can be rescued and diverted. Today, 
unsellable food that is diverted from the 
waste stream is donated, sent to animal feed, 
industrial uses, or composted, depending on 
numerous factors. Food that is not diverted is 
sent to landfill or incineration. 
WHAT’S NEXT
In November 2020, we joined the U.S. 
Food Loss and Waste 2030 Champions–a 
collaborative effort led by the U.S. EPA and 
USDA. We also completed national and 
integrated waste and recycling contracts 
early in the 2021 fiscal year. 
Our focus in 2021 we will be on standardizing 
programs, operating procedures, policies, 
signage, and training our associates to drive 
improved performance. We will continue to 
work toward increasing source reduction and 
food waste diversion alike to meet our new 
goal of cutting food waste at our distribution 
centers in half by 2025, five years ahead of the 
UN Sustainable Development goal. 
NEW GOAL
50% reduction in distribution center food 
waste by 2025
